column3: feature_description
column6: reasoning

column2: Curfew login blocker with ASL and GH for Utah minors
column3: To comply with the Utah Social Media Regulation Act, we are implementing a curfew-based login restriction for users under 18. The system uses ASL to detect minor accounts and routes enforcement through GH to apply only within Utah boundaries. The feature activates during restricted night hours and logs activity using EchoTrace for auditability. This allows parental control to be enacted without user-facing alerts, operating in ShadowMode during initial rollout.
column6: The feature implements a curfew-based login restriction for minors and is specifically designed to comply with the Utah Social Media Regulation Act, applying only within Utah boundaries. This triggers requirements for parental controls and night-time curfews.

column2: PF default toggle with NR enforcement for California teens
column3: As part of compliance with California’s SB976, the app will disable PF by default for users under 18 located in California. This default setting is considered NR to override, unless explicit parental opt-in is provided. Geo-detection is handled via GH, and rollout is monitored with FR logs. The design ensures minimal disruption while meeting the strict personalization requirements imposed by the law.
column6: The feature disables the personalized feed by default for users under 18 located in California, which is done to comply with California's . This falls under the California Age-Appropriate Design Code, which requires high-privacy defaults for minors. External law reference(s) removed: SB976. Not in reference context; set to UNSURE.

column2: Child abuse content scanner using T5 and CDS triggers
column3: In line with the US federal law requiring providers to report child sexual abuse content to NCMEC, this feature scans uploads and flags suspected materials tagged as T5. Once flagged, the CDS auto-generates reports and routes them via secure channel APIs. The logic runs in real-time, supports human validation, and logs detection metadata for internal audits. Regional thresholds are governed by LCP parameters in the backend.
column6: The feature scans uploads for child sexual abuse material and reports it. This aligns with the US federal law requiring providers to report child sexual abuse content to NCMEC. The implementation location is not explicitly stated, but the feature description mentions alignment with US federal law, so the US federal rule applies.

column2: Content visibility lock with NSP for EU DSA
column3: To meet the transparency expectations of the EU Digital Services Act, we are introducing a visibility lock for flagged user-generated content labeled under NSP. When such content is detected, a soft Softblock is applied and GH ensures enforcement is restricted to the EU region only. EchoTrace supports traceability, and Redline status can be triggered for legal review. This feature enhances accountability and complies with Article 16’s removal mechanisms.
column6: The feature description explicitly mentions compliance with the EU Digital Services Act and restricts enforcement to the EU region. The feature handles user-generated content and implements removal mechanisms, which triggers the need to consider data protection regulations. Therefore, EU is applicable. External law reference(s) removed: GDPR. Not in reference context; set to UNSURE.

column2: Jellybean-based parental notifications for Florida regulation
column3: To support Florida's Online Protections for Minors law, this feature extends the Jellybean parental control framework. Notifications are dispatched to verified parent accounts when a minor attempts to access restricted features. Using IMT, the system checks behavioral anomalies against BB models. If violations are detected, restrictions are applied in ShadowMode with full audit logging through CDS. Glow flags ensure compliance visibility during rollout phases.
column6: The feature implements parental controls and notifications specifically to support Florida's online protection laws for minors. This triggers requirements under the Florida Minor Online Safety Requirements.

column2: Unified retention control via DRT & CDS
column3: Introduce a data retention feature using DRT thresholds, ensuring automatic log deletion across all regions. CDS will continuously audit retention violations, triggering EchoTrace as necessary. Spanner logic ensures all platform modules comply uniformly.
column6: The feature description involves data retention and deletion of logs across all regions, which may include the EU. If personal data is processed, EU requirements for data retention, deletion, and auditing of compliance would apply. External law reference(s) removed: GDPR. Not in reference context; set to UNSURE.

column3: This feature will automatically detect and tag content that violates NSP policy. Once flagged, Softblock is applied and a Redline alert is generated if downstream sharing is attempted.
column6: The feature description involves content moderation and flagging, which could potentially trigger legal requirements depending on the nature of the content and the location of implementation. However, the implementation location is not specified, so it is not possible to determine which jurisdiction's laws might apply. Therefore, I cannot determine if this feature requires geo-specific legal compliance logic.

column3: When users report content containing high-risk information, it is tagged as T5 for internal routing. CDS then enforces escalation. The system is universal and does not rely on regional toggles or GH routes.
column6: The feature tags user-reported content containing high-risk information and escalates it via CDS (Compliance Detection System). Because the system is universal and does not rely on regional toggles, the NCMEC reporting rule applies. If the high-risk information includes apparent CSAM, the online service must report it to NCMEC without delay and preserve relevant data for law enforcement.

column3: Snowcap is activated for all underage users platform-wide, applying ASL to segment accounts. Actions taken under this logic are routed to CDS and monitored using BB to identify deviations in usage.
column6: The feature description states that age-sensitive logic is applied to segment accounts of underage users platform-wide. This triggers compliance detection and monitoring of user behavior. Because the feature impacts children and involves monitoring behavior, regulations regarding children's online privacy and safety may apply. Since no specific location is mentioned, I will assume that the feature is implemented in the US. Therefore, Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (`us_coppa`) may apply.

column2: Universal PF deactivation on guest mode
column3: By default, PF will be turned off for all uses browsing in guest mode.
column6: The feature deactivates the personalized feed in guest mode. This is a business rollout decision rather than a legal requirement.

column2: Flag escalation flow for sensitive comments

column2: Custom avatar system with identity checks
column3: Users can now design custom avatars. For safety, T5 triggers block adult-themed assets from use by underage profiles. Age detection uses ASL and logs flow through GH.
column6: The feature allows users to create custom avatars and blocks adult-themed assets from underage profiles. Age detection is used, and the feature logs flow through a geo-handler. Since the feature uses age detection and handles user data, it is subject to regulations regarding children's data. Because the implementation location is not specified, I will assume that the feature is implemented in the US. Therefore, Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (`us_coppa`) may apply.
